This is the best game ever made. The only bugs are the ones you shoot at, the difficulty, scale, and complexity are all perfect. As big as the learning curve is, it's enjoyable the whole way, just make sure to watch  yt tutorials and read the wiki when you get stuck on something.

The graphics and art are beautiful, the machines are cool to look at, and the bugs subconsciously make me reach for the can of raid. When you eventually collapse the ecosystem of Nauvis, you will notice the trees die and the algae in the water increases and gives it a stagnant look.

The sound is pleasing to listen too, The rumbling chaos of the factory never gets old, you have plenty of alarms and sirens that you can configure to play during certain conditions, I have an air raid siren that gives me a sense of urgency when my firewall runs out of oil. Solid music as well.


10/10 story. You're a deranged engineer that crashed on what's basically the alien planet from starship troopers and after conquering said world you end up staying to flex more on nature because you can.

Factorio is exactly what it says it is and excels at it. The game offers great experience to players of all types - there's some real meat in the stats for players who want to dive into the details and optimize things, aliens to defend yourself from and eventually eradicate, or if you just want to calmly build a cool base, then that's fine too. There's the goal of building a rocket to escape the planet, but with so many ways and reasons to play and learn, you probably won't.

Despite mostly being a generally deep and engaging game, aliens in Factorio feel like an afterthought. There's a whole side of the game dedicated to fighting back against a zerg-like alien threat. They get more powerful and aggressive as the game goes on, but dealing with them is a hassle instead of being a fun part of the game. There's really only two types - ranged and melee - and all they do is run at your bases mindlessly. You don't get anything for dealing with them, your only option is to fight them, and until then they just stand around. There's good gameplay in building and maintaining defenses, and the concept is solid, but the aliens themselves are mindless, bland, and ultimately boring.

There have been many nights when I played this game that I looked at the clock and it started at 9:00 PM and after playing for what I assumed as an hour or two I check back and it has actually been 5 hours instead and is 2:00 AM. This game is truly wonderful if you're looking for a game that is infinite map with finite resource patches  that will give you an insane amount of $ per hour this is the game. If you're looking for a game that has high complexity but a low entry requirement this is the game for you. If you're looking for a game that you can sink well over 100-200 hours per save this is the game for you. All in All I would rate this game among the top of my entire library. With the release of Space Age adding new complexity and features that's a net positive for it. I can not recommend this game highly enough. It scratches an itch to build a massive rail system to feed your factory.
All in All.

Holy cow what a game. Great for analytical thinkers and creative problem solvers alike. It's approachable enough that I think most people can beat it if they want to put in the effort (and there's a good time to be had even if you're gunna just get to oil processing and stop), and there's so much depth that a computer science degree is a distinct advantage for making cool stuff and going beyond the natural end of the game. Great mod support for both gameplay overhauls and quality of life improvements. Factorio [i]never[/i] goes on sale, and the devs have said it never will. $35 might seem like a lot for an indie game on steam but it's totally worth every penny. For my playtime at time of writing this review, that's about $0.10 per hour of entertainment, and I still have a [i]huge[/i] list of mods to play and factory designs I want to try. If it's on your wishlist, I highly recommend you take the plunge and give it a try.

I've had a long journey with Factorio. I purchased it in the summer of 2020 after having it on my wishlist for some time, but didn't put much time into it right away. I started back up in 2022 and my old save file was out of date, so I started a new factory. I built it up all the way to getting utility (yellow) science packs and started researching the silo. I burned out and life got busy, and it wasn't until last month (Sep 2024) that I saw that the DLC was coming out soon and set out to beat the game before the DLC release. I pushed through, fought off some biters to get to more iron (which I'd run out of), and was able to get that rocket launched today! So if you want a part-time job, get this game!

I have 252 hours in-game and I'm surprised I haven't written a comment about this gem yet. Factorio is incredibly engaging, offering a perfect blend of strategy, simulation, and resource management. Building and optimizing factories is both challenging and rewarding, keeping you hooked for hours on end.

If you enjoy games like Minecraft (with a focus on automation), Satisfactory, or RimWorld, you'll likely love Factorio. It's ideal for players who appreciate complex problem-solving and meticulous planning. The game has a steep learning curve but offers immense satisfaction as you progress.

Highly recommended for anyone looking for a deep and immersive experience that tests your strategic thinking and creativity.

11/10 Highly Recommend

What the fuck is this price increase, Wube?!
I bought this game for about R$50.00 (which I think was totally worth it and a fair price), it doubled in price since then.
Currently it's R$101.00! that's SEVEN PERCENT of the national minimum monthly salary.

Let me put this into perspective, in the USA, the federal minimum hourly wage (which in my understanding it's not really even close to what people are really paid there) is $7.25, that means you need to work about 5 hours to purchase this game.

Lets compare that with Brazil's R$1,412.00 minimum monthly salary (for context that salary is for 220 monthly hours of work, and is, in fact, what a lot of people survive on here): R$1,412.00 / 220h ~= R$6.41/h
That's, rounding down, 15 hours of minimum wage work to buy Factorio.

That is fucking insane.

Let me be clear here, I'm not saying Wube couldn't have changed the price in Brazil, I'm saying a 100% increase in price is insulting and frankly a stupid decision from a business standpoint.
A 16% price change (like what happened in USD) would put the game at R$58, lets round that to R$60, and up it to R$65, cause why not, the game is good.
That's still a reasonable price, I wouldn't be writing all this because of a 30% price increase, it would suck, but hey, inflation and economy things and shit.

I hope that this was a mistake in Wube's part, and that they notice that their price change in USD broke the regional pricing... Until then this review will unfortunately stay negative.

Probably the most deeply satisfying, simple yet complex, absorbing experience I have ever experienced in gaming. Nothing beats the construction of a huge, complex factory which begins to flow with the blood of copper and iron once the power gets switched on. That kind of thing is just so pleasing to watch and so satisfying to build. Electricity, logistics, expandibility, spacing, ratios, production numbers, defenses... every aspect of this game works so well with each other that it never feels fragmented. It is a totally cohesive experience. I could rant for hours about this game but currently I'm working on a guide to do that sort of ranting, so for this review we'll keep it simple. This game is awesome. Definitely in my top three. There is simply no other game I've played like it, and now because of this I need to play more factory management games. If you have a bunch of free time or need a game to latch onto for a bit, play this. If you have autism or like practicing math and blueprinting in a digital space, play this game. Are you an engineer or programmer? Playing this game is basically just practicing all the skills of your job, but in a game. I can't wait to go unemployed when the DLC drops later this month. Even for 35 bucks, this game is a steal. 10/10. The factory must grow.

Factorio is a good game.

it has a certain addictive quality, as you build your base from one part to the next. Some parts, are challenging, mostly limited by your own force of will, but over time your will grows and you become a master engineer, developing a vast industrial empire and laying waste to those who would oppose you. 

Progression is well-balanced, and there's enough of a challenge but never one that is insurmountable.

Factorio has an excellent development team and an active modding community adding rich depth and support to a game, keeping it fresh even after years of playtime.

I can't guarantee it's for everyone, but if you pursue the demo which I believe is still out there, you can find it and give the game a try - the first bit is a small but accurate taste of the rest.

This game will not go on sale. Take a leap of faith, preferably after the demo, and join our exalted hall of engineers.

I love this game. I have spent the last few years trying to find another automation game that ignites the same spark in me that Factorio does. I have come close, but Factorio continues to be my favorite. You might be looking at it alongside other games with fancy ray-tracing Unreal Engine graphics and wondering why Factorio should be the game you play.

Using that fancy GPU to trace those rays is well and good. But those fancy rays are not helping your factory. They'll get in your way as you try to expand your iron processing capacity. Factorio knows what you really want to use that fancy gaming computer for... pushing more iron plates. Factorio does not need fancy rays, because it has that unfiltered, uncut automation gameplay that it inject directly into your veins. No fancy rays required.

Factorio is a topdown factory builder that takes place on a hostile alien planet. You start humble but effective, for the time being. Not before long, you will need to rapidly automate and expand the factory functions, while repelling and maybe even countering the alien threat. It's not the most overwhelming experience, facing the aliens. The greatest brainmelt will be of your own making, as your rush to survival most likely consisted of a spaghetti of conveyers and assemblers, sprawling out and becoming convoluted until expansion requires you to simply move and build it again, with better planning. This may ward off many players, so be ready for it spiritually, and also be sure to overestimate how much of something you will need, as it's better than the opposite. The good Factorio player will be able to construct efficient factories of enourmous sizes, though for the story goal, it won't be so complicated. Of course, I know this despite my short playtime because I saw the game online a few times before ever buying it and playing, though it was still a fresh and joyous experience to pick it up myself and learn more than I knew. A new DLC is coming out as of this review, so now is the time to pick this game up and build factories, if you dare.

As if anyone would need another "Steam" review for this game...
As if anyone would even stumble on this single review...
As if anyone who didn't buy this game yet, would spend time reading my review...
As if anyone who did buy this game would need a break, since they didn't touch grass or talked to someone in a month...

If you're still here, you might be willing to buy it or try to convince yourself that you don't have a problem and that you're not alone with a gaming addiction. You know, there's help available for you and its usually going through the library menu and click on the "Play" button on the upper left corner, after 100-200 more hours, you will have forgotten about it.

That's what i tell myself once in a while when i come to the comments section, to remind myself that I'm not alone. After 6 years & close to 4000 hours, i came through this dark place a few times already and it's still fun reading other addicts talking about the hype they still have for it or seeing new addicts, not knowing they are addicts, yet giving it a thumbs up not knowing what they got themselves into. Most of us got a cool nick name for this game, you will learn it eventually when you get old enough or read enough reviews.

To begin with...

I would state that the last time I've read the definition of the words limitless or boundless in the Oxford dictionary, i had to read it twice because i wasn't convinced that it was accurate. I submitted reviews to add a section for these words about this game, but unfortunately it has been rejected since these words were slightly underwhelming to define Factorio. I've since been learning Spanish, French, Japanese, Norwegian, German and Danish in the search of enlightenment, but I have yet to find a proper word for it.

I've played many games of the genre over the years, many of them are above and beyond, but as of today this one is the only one still installed because all my saves filled up my 80 TB NAS storage and I don't have anymore place to install anything. I might be exaggerating a bit tho, but if you ever end up with a 1 TB save file you will remember me.

I've played a lot of hours in early access and had to stop because I was limited by the technology of my time. How it is possible would you ask? This game is so optimised, its impossible!! Are you yelling at your monitor again? Let me ask you then, have you seen that video where that guy walk to the edge of the map? Yea, that's what i though, you didn't. Take a break, go on YT and come back. Fortunately some company figured out the magic for this game and I'm back at it.

As of today, I'm planning my retirement around this game in about 30 years. I've got myself a shack deep in the wood with a few solar panels and will be designing blueprints until then to get myself ready to build something to hang on the walls since i will probably have amnesia and dementia by then by watching belts going in all directions.

About the game...

This game....i don't know how to describe it since the dictionary is not up to date for the task, but I guess I can put some words together to give you an idea. It's "Ok". I would imagine that this answer is not up to your expectation after all this, but it is what it is, thousands of peoples playing thousands of hours and still playing, still planning, still finding out new patterns and tricks.

Either if you're an engineer or a school bus driver, the game will let you have fun the way you want to have fun. If you want it easy or painful, there's something for you. You want to spend 100 hours building a processor within the game to play Doom or if you just want to watch trains, both ways will let you launch a rocket, even tho one of them might be rocket science.

In conclusion...

Set an alarm to not forget to go to sleep.
Don't forget your pets still need food and water.
You still have to do your taxes once a year.
Call your parents once in a while.

The price increase is actually in line with inflation, at least in the US. Their costs are going up due to inflation. Every price cost goes up with inflation. Why should software be any different? I can't remember why I decided to play the demo and to be honest, the demo doesn't really tell you what the game is about. I also remember seeing Factorio years ago and not liking the aesthetics much. A sprite based game didn't look like something I would be into. However I do like building games, Anno 1404 comes to mind.

So why am I still playing this game, even after I played trough it once and specially now that Satisfactorio is out. Honestly, it is about overcoming your own limitations more than it is about beating the game. I like to play games on a harder difficulty to challenge myself. Moreover, you can solve problems over and over by starting on a new map or by just giving yourself a handicap. And if all that is to boring then surely one of the infinite Mods will do the trick.

[b]Just play the demo.[/b] You will get some basics explained. Now, imagine a huge amount of resources needed and a lot of space filled with inserters and belts. If you look at playtime on Steam, you will realise that it's not a 10h game (unless you are speedrunning XD). So be prepared to keep playing until you fall asleep and start over more than once.

FYI. The game really only has one scenario you can play. You can create randomised maps and control most parameters. If you want a very relaxed approach to the game then turning of the enemy or making them not aggressive is a good option.

I will be playing this game for many more hours and the commitment of the developer makes this a worthwhile game.

In this dark, atmospheric adventure, players step into the shoes of a brooding vigilante, navigating through a notorious psychiatric facility overrun by deranged criminals. The narrative kicks off with the protagonist capturing a sinister clown, only to find that the entire situation was a trap. What unfolds is a tense, psychological battle as the hero is forced to face some of the most dangerous villains lurking in the facility’s depths.

The combat system is fluid and engaging, allowing players to seamlessly chain attacks and counters while taking on multiple enemies. It’s more than just brute force, though; the game emphasizes the hero’s detective prowess, as players solve intricate puzzles, investigate crime scenes, and use an arsenal of gadgets to outsmart their foes. Stealth also plays a crucial role, encouraging players to methodically plan their attacks and take out enemies from the shadows.

The setting is perfectly designed to evoke a sense of isolation and dread, with eerie corridors, hidden secrets, and larger-than-life encounters with villains that challenge the hero both physically and mentally. The balance between combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving creates a well-rounded and immersive experience.

This game expertly captures the essence of what it means to be a lone warrior in a world of chaos, using brains as much as brawn to restore order.

actorio is hands down one of the most satisfying and addictive games I’ve ever played. The level of detail and depth in designing and optimizing complex factory systems is unmatched. From mining resources to building intricate conveyor belts, factories, and automating every process, the gameplay is an endless loop of rewarding creativity and problem-solving. Every time I improve my factory's efficiency or discover new automation techniques, it feels like a major accomplishment. The game’s balance between challenge and creativity keeps me coming back for more, always wanting to perfect my setups and streamline production.

The community is fantastic, and the mods offer endless ways to customize and enhance the experience. The developers are also incredibly dedicated, continuously improving the game with updates that add value without ever losing the core experience. Factorio strikes the perfect balance between strategy, creativity, and engineering that few games manage to achieve.

As for Factorio 2.0, I couldn’t be more excited! Knowing the developers' commitment to quality and depth, I’m eager to see what new features, mechanics, and innovations they will introduce. The potential for expanded gameplay, improved graphics, and even more complex factory systems has me counting down the days. Factorio has already set a gold standard for automation games, and I can’t wait to dive into a bigger, better, and more refined experience with 2.0! This is going to be a must-play for any fan of the genre.

One of the best games ever made that created the genre of addicting factory builders. Probably has the best devs of any game as well. I have owned this game for a long time, only just now getting around to writing a review. This is one of those games you will always come back to periodically. It has infinite replayability because you always think of better ways you could have done things and theres so many mods that overhaul the entire game. Truly a masterpiece.

I want to dispel a few myths about this game though. Firstly you don't need to have a high IQ or be a programmer to enjoy this game (cue the rick and morty copypasta). This is a sandbox game with no incorrect ways to play. You can do basic math to figure out ratios of assemblers or you can just dump everything on a belt and add more machines of whatever is bottlenecking you. Both will get the job done equally well. You will figure out ideal setups of basic components like green circuits pretty quickly (or you can lookup blueprints other people have made online if you want) but not everything needs to be ratio perfect. The main gameplay loop is just make more of whatever you are short on. Which is very addicting. If anything, I think this game is harder if you have OCD or are a perfectionist because you will spend forever trying to think of the perfect setup but the most effecient way to play is to just throw more assemblers down as quickly as possible.

Trains can be very intimidating for new players but they really aren't that complicated and definitely worth learning. Basically just always make two parallel tracks just like the lanes of a road and have them only drive on the right. Then anytime you have an intersection just put chain signals at all the entrances and normal signals at all the exits. It's pretty much that simple. Once you have trains setup your base is no longer limited by it's ore patches, you can just keep making outposts and feeding it forever. Plus the throughput of trains can't really be beaten.

As for bots, technically you can use logistic bots for pretty much everything. It's as simple as putting down a requester chest with the necessary ingredients and a provider chest and the bots will handle it. The issue I have with this practice is that it kind of trivializes the game. Increasing throughput is as simple as just adding more bots to the network. And the game is so well optimized that there is practically no limit to how many bots you can add. And again, it's sandbox game so you can play anyway you want obviously, but to me using bots for everything feels like cheating. Personally, I use them to construct things obviously and to bring me stuff. For everything else I like to use belts. That way you have to plan things out because it actually matters where you place everything. But that's just my opinion.

As for biters, I think the community is fairly evenly split on them. Personally, most of my hours have been played with no biters, as I just find them annoying when I am trying to plan out my base. But they definitely do add a significant challenge to the game both in terms of the mental toll that they take as well as the extra resources they require you to spend on defenses. I would recommend new players that are struggling to launch a rocket to just turn them off because they put you on a clock where you must progress fast enough to outpace their evolution. Which is stressful when you are just trying to learn the basics. And once you git gud at the game and can spreedrun through the tech tree they aren't much of an issue on normal settings anyway. So at that point you can either play on deathworld if you enjoy that sort of thing or you can turn them off and focus on building megabases. Both are valid ways to play.

I didn't think that I was the type of person who would enjoy Factorio -- everyone in my orbit who had sunk their teeth into this game already had some greater enjoyment of engineering principles, coding, science etc., so for a very long time I wrote it off as one of those games that just wasn't for me. If this sounds familiar to you, this review's for you.

I bought Factorio once before and refunded it when I joined in on two friends starting a new save and speaking game terms like conversational greek. I was correct that it wasn't for me - at the time. On a whim, much later, I gave it another shot after I saw a convincing review for Satisfactory under the thesis of 'gameifying the part of your brain that rewards productivity,' and thought 'well -- that looks a lot less exhausting in 2D, and Factorio is the more polished of the two, as far as I can tell.'

Start with the free demo - it eases you into all the important concepts and will be a pretty good test of whether you want to commit to a full purchase. When I did, it became readily apparent that this isn't just a game for STEMheads (although it certainly attracts the type), but for problem-solvers. Each step in the gameplay loop is a new logistical puzzle with clear goals, varied constraints and obstacles based on your mapgen and tech level, and infinite solutions to take you to the finish line. 

You will amaze yourself as the game finds a new way to make you feel like a wizard every few hours, taking yourself from hand-stuffing lumps of coal into stone kilns to forge crude iron, to smelting steel in electric furnaces, to waving your hand and watching your army of helper automatons slap down in seconds a perfect copy of the 32-furnace smelting complex you designed hours ago. You'll take yourself from running on a rough forest floor to driving over concrete, and from driving over concrete to zipping to the south pole in your rocket-fuel-powered trains to check on your nuclear reactors. It's seamless, intuitive, and downright astonishing.

Endless possibilities = endless fun. Cue the 'Oh my God, I get it' frame -- Factorio is one of the greatest games of all time.

I got obsessed with this game. Not in a good way. This is a game of engineering and logistics. The basic loop is that you have to mine resources, then figure out a way to get those resources to factories, where they spit out refined resources, which are used to make more stuff, and so on and on. And this can become addicting as you unlock more and more options--conveyor belts, faster conveyor belts, cargo trains, solar power plants, etc. All this is cumulating towards the ingredients you need to fly off the planet. Meanwhile, you also have to fend off aliens who don't like your pollution and deal with power shortages. 

From the screenshots, it looks like everything you build is nicely organized and efficient. But it all ends up becoming a big big mess with conveyor belts criss-crossing everywhere, electric poles stretching across the continent, and you trying to squeeze out just a drop more efficiency out of that "science potion" generator. Maybe I'm just bad at designing things, but at a certain point, you're just kind of playing to see the end. And the end SUCKS. It's worse than a LJN Nintendo game that says "conglaturation".

So I took a "break" (I didn't need one, just played other games). I came back after a few years. 
I. Am. Impressed.
This dev team is GOOD. The sound design, all of the new sprites, even the freakin flashlight... this team isn't content with "good enough" - they go the extra mile. And it shows. Well f'ing done to everyone at Wube!

That said, if you like tickling your creative solutions gray matter, this game is for you. Dyson Sphere, Satisfactory, and the dozens of other factory sims that have recently hit the market - all of them owe their success in some way to Factorio. It popularized the factory sim category and set standards that the others have yet to meet. I really cannot recommend this game enough. 

Overwhelmed? Watch Katherine of Sky or Nilaus on Youtube. Need more challenge (you masochist you!)? Check out the in-game mod menu. 

Get it. You won't regret it.

This game scratches that problem solving itch, because it's not prescriptive in the approach you take and you can generally go at your own pace. I have two bits of advice to anyone just starting:

- SPREAD OUT! There is plenty of space on the map! No need to cram everything neatly into every nook and cranny because it will only cause headaches later when you need to add a new belt or expand the manufacturing capacity of some part.

- Make lots of parts! Better to overestimate how many parts you'll need and have some production units go unused then to not make enough and slow down the whole process.

I have the hardest time determining what to write about the games I love the most. As hundreds of hours pile up, trying to compress the successes and the failures, the triumphs and the catastrophes, all the myriad experiences the game has to offer into a single review seems impossible.

Even if I could, it would be long and no one would read it.

As it is, if you're reading this, you're thinking about buying Factorio, so you probably already have some idea of what you're looking at. This is a game about automation, like the trailer says. It's about starting small and learning to make bigger things. Which will then give you the resources to make even more complex, even larger things. And then when you get so unbelievably good at that that it seems like you've seen all there is to see or do, you face a crossroads:

You could stop there. Or you could go deeper. Build it all faster. Make it all more efficient. Use the unbelievably convenient built-in mod support and play one of the total overhaul mods; experience someone else's perspective on the tech tree and end goals. Make the biters insanely powerful and turn the game into a tower defense...or play one of the mods that [i]actually[/i] makes the game a tower defense game. 

Build anything. Do everything. Explore because you can. Make a self-expanding base that auto-eliminates biter nests. Die a thousand times to biters in the Rampant mod with the settings ramped up before you even make basic advancements.

But it all starts simple. Just mining some minerals out of the ground. For now, at the starting line, you don't need to worry about where it's all headed. Set up some burner drills. Learn the basics of automation...and see where it takes you.

A ridiculously well polished game. 

I've played all 1k hours of it entirely on a Steam Deck. I'll usually run at a solid 60 FPS, and often in 4k when docked, and while I didn't really get into mega bases, the only performance issues I've encountered in my normal play through were the trees, which for whatever reason when in very high density tend to cause the game to perform poorly on the Deck... by which I mean it drops to "only" 40 FPS while in 4k. 

The only changes I've made to the controls up until now is adding a mouse gyro configuration. The game doesn't support mixed controller/keyboard inputs (gotta switch between them in settings) but it supports mixed mouse/controller inputs very well, so setting up gyro is super easy. The only bug I'll encounter once in a while is the cursor's texture visibility bugging in and out while in a menu.

I've had absolutely no trouble with readability of anything within the interface. All things are a good size for reading by default, irrelevant of resolution or screen size. The game's entire set of tutorials and tooltips support controller inputs directly, so you'll constantly be reminded of what buttons can do what and get to learn the majority of the common keybindings without any external resources. I've played the good 500 first hours of the game without any internet. The game's built in zoom feature is more than enough to ensure you can always have good visibility of what you're trying to do in the game world, all while making the best use of your current screen size, whether you're docked or not. It's definitely the type of game you can just randomly pickup for half an hour and drop off whenever you need to.

To put it simply, this game is simply wonderful to play on a Steam Deck.

If you've enjoyed games like Satisfactory, Dyson Sphere Program, MegaFactory TItan, or any other in that vein, then you need to play Factorio. I believe it's one of the best in that genre, even though It's not the prettiest to look at and the price rarely drops below $29.99.

I was never smart enough (or willing to watch enough YouTube vids) to build a ridiculous logistic network mega base that evolved beyond conveyor belts. But there are so many creative and technically workable solutions in this game, that if you put the time and energy into it, you can learn to unravel a convoluted spaghetti monster of a system and feel like you're making real progress.

There's a sequel coming soon, which I will definitely buy, so I will now happily put this into the archive of 'great games'.

I finally launched a rocket after starting and restarting over the years. The learning curve intimidated me for a long time. I felt a lot of pressure to move quickly and not waste resources. The stress of figuring new things out led me to endless, meaningless optimizations on the stuff I already built, and when I couldn't do that anymore I'd give up and stop playing for several more months.

If you think this might happen to you, I recommend turning up resource richness; even just by 33%. This will reduce the stress of running low on your starting resources and give you time for early failures. 

Have fun trying things out! If you learn to enjoy the process of solving the more difficult problems the game presents, you'll have a blast with it.

It was in the midst of playing a recent Statech Industries run in MC 1.19.2 that it dawned upon me, Kovarex (holy be his name) saw the light many years before me, automation in any other game is the false prophet. he set it upon himself to create a figure of The Lord and Saviour. 

Automation mods in any game will only mirror the greatness of a game focused on automation, no mod will sate my hunger and thirst for a game in which the factory must grow, no sound will ever be close to the loud wirr of assemblers, no "windmill" will ever replicate the soft buzz of a solar accumulator field, no mob or enemy shall match the looming threat of another biter hoard, ready to pounce on your low ammo gun turrets. Nothing will ever beat factorio in what it does, it is and will remain the greatest. Anything attempting it is a mere mockery.

This is a game that does what it does, and it does it perfectly. It's worth it at full price.

A note for those who may be in the same boat as me as a modestly technical player, but not quite fully knowledgeable or committed like many are: the game's scope expands drastically once you reach trains and oil processing. I never played the demo, so I don't know how much content it includes, so it's obviously a good idea to try if you haven't.

If you're more of a "wing it" kind of guy like myself and don't rely much on blueprints, like minute details such as calculating throughput, don't have a very organized production chain, or aren't quite clever enough to create elegant and efficient solutions for a multitude of logistical hurdles you may come across, then you may hit a wall there.

Still, the early game stuff is still engrossing enough to get plenty of hours from.

One of the best if not THE best game about engineering. If you actively enjoy computer programming, you're likely to enjoy Factorio. If you're considering a career in computer programming, it might be worth trying Factorio to quickly and cheaply gather proxy evidence about your possible enjoyment of your planned career. (Some of the above may also apply to some other engineering disciplines -- I wouldn't know.)

Factorio is extremely well-made. It's approximately bug-free. It's so well-optimized, that you can probably finish the game on a low-end device without encountering any performance issues.

A complete playthrough took me about 100 hours -- though I also started and aborted a few games when I was first learning, which brings the time to my first completion up into the ~150 hour range. The game has very little time pressure, though. Much slower and much faster completions are entirely possible. Experiment, learn and build at your own pace.

After you finish the main game, I highly recommend a fresh playthrough with the excellent Space Exploration mod, available though the in-game mod portal. It adds space-based threats like meteors to detect/shoot down/mine and dangerous solar flares, and a post-game in which you expand to orbit, to (the) moon(s) and other planets, and even to nearby stars.
